title: Do high school students ever go back to elementary school? - Quora

response.answer_text: As a student, no. It would be a disaster for the teenager to be in a learning environment where some of their peers are a decade younger than them. I also imagine the parents of the young children would be upset about a teenager in the class. Once graduating college, the high schooler can go back to elementary school as a teacher, but they will no longer be a high schooler or a teenager. If a high school student feels they are academically at a much lower level than the grade they are enrolled, there are many options to solve this. Find a tutor or mentor to help you improve on missing knowledge and skills. Talk to the teachers and counselors at school to see what resources the school can offer. Look into what homeschooling can do to accelerate your learning process. I’m sure there are lots of other options, this is just what comes to the top of mind.

response.answer_text: If a high school student needs remedial learning, elementary school wouldn’t provide what they need. It would go too slow. It would spend too much time on material they already understand. They’d have a hard time relating to their fellow students. ;-) It’s a fallacy that school neatly doles out all the material people need in 12 precise packets that each take 9 months to learn. In school there’s a massive amount of repetition. That’s because schools are set up for students to memorize, not to understand the material. Humans don’t memorize that well. That’s why school takes so long. It’s an attractive idea to start all over from the beginning to “do it right” this time. If that’s what you’re wondering. But it’s pure fantasy. If a high school student was struggling they would do far better with a tutor who could focus on the specific areas where they were having problems. They wouldn’t need to waste time with stuff they already know. Unschooled kids don’t do school-style learning. They spend their time learning through exploring their interests. Those who want to go onto college, don’t need to spend 12 years studying what they “missed”. Some go right into college. Some find it useful to take a semester or two of math and English. That gets them up to speed on formal math notation and writing. That’s generally all they need to get what kids in school spend 12 years learning.
A2A. Not as a student, no. They may go back to visit former teachers and reminisce. But if students need academic help, they should find support and remedial classes in the high school.
No. The moment you graduate you can’t go back.
